text: A DEAD CAT on the side of the road. Flies swarm around. C pass. Then, a thunderous rumble. The large tires of a PEN YELLOW SCHOOL BUS approach and come into focus.

The bus barrels down the two-lane blacktop, cutting throu the wooded countryside. JEFF DAHMER, 16, gazes out the window. His blank face is hidden behind WIRE-RIMMED GLASSES and SHAGGY, TOWHEADED H His eyes track the roadkill as the bus drives past.

Full of jabbering TEENAGERS. Awkward freshman sit closer the front. Cooler kids own the back rows. In a middle row, Jeff is by his lonesome. Three average teenagers in the row directly in front of h play Twenty Questions:
Is it a person?
Yes.
Is the person living?
Yes.
Is the person famous?

Sort of. The Bus driver grips the steering wheel as the bus hits a cluster of potholes. Everyone bounces, but no pause to th antics.  JOHN “DERF” BACKDERF, 17, sits in the front. He has a subversive confidence. Already resigned to his band-nerd status, he no longer gives a shit. He RIPS OUT a page fro his pad:
Dang it. The bumpy ride ruined his cartoon. He starts a new sketch that mocks the Bus Driver clenching the steering wheel:

Calm down in the back. Sit down... The bus thunders along and turns onto WEST BATH ROAD. Jeff's eyes land on a NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER, late 40s, hand and lean, running in the same direction as the bus. He’s dressed in classic 70s running attire: Nikes, color strip tube socks, Adidas shorts. The bus stops. Several kids unload. The jogger runs ahead The bus picks up speed. Again, Jeff's eyes lock on the Neighborhood Jogger. Jeff studies the jogger’s stride, hi arms moving back & forth, thighs pumping, his stoic face. The bus accelerates. The Neighborhood Jogger starts to disappear behind the bus in the distance. Jeff heads up the aisle to the rear emergency exit door, trying to keep his sights on the jogger. He’s oddly fixat BUS DRIVER (CONT’D) Sit down in the back. Can’t see. Who is that? The front row freshmen shrug. They don’t know. BUS DRIVER (CONT’D) Hey! Other kids on the bus don’t know either. BUS DRIVER (CONT’D) Who's that? Derf looks up from his drawing pad.
(eye rolls) That’s Jeff Dahmer.
Jeff. Sit down. Jeff gets a tap on the shoulder. He turns around.
But I didn’t do anything. Jeff returns to his seat. The bus accelerates again...
The bus dumps Jeff and some other kids off at their stop.

Jeff steps up to the edge of the driveway and waits. Ther again, the Neighborhood Jogger approaches. Getting closer Jeff smiles, yet afraid to wave, as the jogger runs right past and continues up the slope. Once the jogger disappears over the hill, Jeff lowers his head and shuffles up the driveway. His shoulders thrust slightly forward. A strangely rigid and inflexible figure The stiff, awkward gait of a kid uncomfortable in the wor
Jeff dumps his backpack on the floor. He heads into the d The hallway walls are lined with dismal wood paneling. He hears chatter around the corner and curiously backtracks.

Jeff enters the living room. A wall of windows looks out the wooded property sloping below. He discovers his fragile mother, JOYCE DAHMER, 41, on the sofa. She flips through a lookbook with MR. BURLMAN, a mi aged man with a slight twitch.
I-I-I think we cud frame the wall of windows with dwapes. Joyce looks up and notices--
Jeff. Hi. What about tennis practice?
Told you already, tennis season ended.  4. Mr. Burlman stands. His knees knock. He wobbles toward Je and extends his hand.
This is Mr. Burlman, my new interior decorator. Mr. Burlman’s twitching escalates.
Hehwo... braaa... Jeff.
Don’t be alarmed. Just a mild case of--
P-p-palsy.
He’s a very talented designer.
Thank you, Mrs. D-d-dahmer.
Hi. Mr. Burlman trembles for a beat, stuck.
N-n-nice to meet you.
Uh-huh. Jeff cuts through and exits the side door to return outsi
Jeff chuckles to himself. The man’s tick amuses him, as i would any teenager.
(to himself) Dwapes.

Jeff treads along the side of the road. Tennis sneakers g against the pebbly dirt. His pace slows. At his feet is the same roadkill, spotted from the bus. H TAPS THE DEAD CAT with his sneaker.  5. Jeff reaches down and picks it up. Holds it preciously in palms. He compulsively squeezes it. A slight sound escape from the decomposing insides. He smirks. Prepared for such a macabre discovery, Jeff pulls a crump plastic bag from his pocket and places the roadkill insid
A bunch of teenagers on bikes maraud down the road. Littl concern for traffic.
c'mon. I don’t wanna miss Monty Python.
Nudge nudge. Wink wink. Know what I mean?
Say no more. Say no more.

Car. The teenagers swoop to the shoulder to let the car pass. keep peddling up the hill, huffing it. Suddenly, a DOG SNARLS at them from the edge of a propert and they peddle quicker, but the incline makes a quick getaway that much harder. SHORTY (CONT’D) We shoulda gone the other way. They run straight into Jeff who’s walking down the hill, carrying his souvenir.
You’re safe. The dog’s harmless and on a chain. The teens catch their breath. They’re immediately curious
Hey, Dahmer. Why are you carrying around... (glances in the bag) Ew!... Dead cat!?!
I’m gonna dissolve it.
Huh?
In some acid.
Whaaat? You’re so fulla crap.
Where did you get acid?
My dad’s a chemist. I can get my hands on it easy.
Yeah right--
Come see if you don’t believe me. They follow Jeff down the hill.
Tucked in the woods on the side of the property, just fif feet from the road, is a MAN-MADE WOODEN SHED. Weeds grow the walls. Jeff and the gang of curious teenagers approac
They enter. A rickety door. A musty space. Assortment of glass jars line the shelves. Each contains a brown, murky substance, individually labeled: Raccoon, Crow, Rabbit, e
Welcome to my science project. Jeff places the dead cat on the table, then retrieves an ALUMINUM CONTAINER.
This acid is kinda weak... so it takes more than a couple of weeks for the flesh to dissolve. He pours acid into an empty jar, then forces the cat insi
Yuck. Jeff pours in some more acid and caps it off.
Wha-wha-why are you doing this?
I like to study bones. It-it interests me. What’s inside...

Aw, this is all total bullcrap! Dead animals, acid, c’mon. I bet these jars are fulla nothin’ but muddy water. Browbeaten beads of sweat dot Jeff's forehead. He pushes and reaches for a jar on a top shelf. Labeled: Raccoon.
See this. I found it a month ago on Hametown Road. The flesh is almost completely dissolved now.

Ha! Yeah right. JEFF SNAPS. He THROWS THE JAR DOWN on the floor, shatteri on impact. Remnants of a half-dissolved raccoon spill out Flesh-pudding and bones. A jawbone. Gnarly raccoon feet. The STENCH is palpable, like a hundred rotten eggs. They gag, bumping into one another as they squeeze out the doo
Jeff and the other teenagers scatter away from the hut, holding their noses, retching. One vomits in the dirt.
Gawd, Dahmer! You are such a freak. The teens run off, abandoning him. Jeff stands alone on t edge of his property - a stiff silhouette.

Jeff's father LIONEL DAHMER, 41, sits at the head of the dining table. A man of high intellect but unable to conne over quotidian details with his chafing wife or two sons, Jeff and DAVE, 10. Lionel serves himself some peas and carrots. Nearby, in t kitchen, Joyce anxiously pulls a chicken out of the oven.
(breaks the silence) Someone pass the iced tea. Dave reaches for it. Jeff takes the pitcher and passes i
How was your day, Dad?
Uneventful.
Mrs. Demeson read more from Charlotte’s Web today--
Dad, is there a stronger chemical I could use? Something that works faster?
Jeff, let your brother speak. What’s the book about, Dave?
It’s a... about a spider who talks to a pig named Wilbur who’s going to be slaughtered by a butcher.
Let me think. Joyce serves an under-cooked chicken.
Jeff, give your brother the drumsticks.
Why? He doesn’t - I like the dark meat.
Jeff. Jeff obliges and gives the two drumsticks to his brother. They pick at the chicken. It’s raw on the bone.
Dad, why is there toilet paper in our trees, again?
I don’t know, son. Jeff lowers his head. Lionel sneaks a peak in his directi  LIONEL (CONT’D) How's tennis, Jeff?
It ended over a week ago. But next year I got a chance to be ranked second singles.
Next fall, how about play some team sports? Or join some clubs... Jeff chokes on his food, and the intimidating suggestion.
Shoot, I forgot the potatoes. Joyce beelines back to the oven.
I’m in the Marching Band too.
I know, but... something new might lead to some better friends. Friends are our connection to the world. Joyce returns with hot potatoes and drops them on the pla
Chicken’s red inside, Mom. Joyce stops moving and examines the table.
You don’t like my cooking? New house rule. We eat our mistakes. Joyce sits. The two boys pick at the food. Lionel and Joy make eye contact across the table. Jeff notes their glare full of resentment.

A drove of students mill about. It’s a quintessential pub high school - soulless, modular formation of red brick. A school bus pulls in and drops off another herd of teenage Some kids gather around the SCHOOL ROCK. This defaced bou is the students’ billboard: graffiti, couples’ initials, the declarations “Balderelli Sucks” and “Class of ‘77 Rul  10.

Jeff walks warily down the overcrowded hall, teeming with 70s trends, hormones, and bravado. Platform shoes. Bell bottoms. Layered long hair and sideburns. “Sabbath Bloody Sabbath” by Black Sabbath blares from a beatbox. Two senior BULLY-JOCKS shove Jeff into the wall--
Outta my way, Dumber! Dumb ass. Jeff slides to the floor. He scurries to pick up his book

Working by himself, Jeff peers into a microscope. Several rows ahead, Derf and two rascally cohorts, KENT a MIKE, joke around. Kent wears a KISS T-shirt, almost alwa He also wears a skeptical attitude. Mike is constantly jovial, with a paunchy, short physique to match. MS. BOWLES, 50s, limps around class. Her metal ankle-brac creaks and distracts, as does her lisp.
Mr. John Backderf. Have you matched, um, the chloroplatz?
We’re workin’ on it, Miss Bowles.
Yeah, we’re on question sixteen to be precise. Ms. Bowles looks at their papers. Derf’s margins are fill with doodles of the girls’ butts in the row ahead.
Gather your stuff.
Me? We’re-we’re taking turns on the scope, Miss--
Over here. With Jeff.
Geez. Ms. Bowles leads Derf to the back row.  11.

Jeff, keep on the same slide and give Mr. Backderf a look. Derf focuses to complete the assignment. MS. BOWLES strol down the side of her classroom and glances in a cabinet. LOCKS EYES on a jarred FETAL PIG on a shelf, unaware Derf now copying his answers.

Jeff carries his tray from the kitchen into a boisterous cafeteria. He sulks past the stereotypical clusters of cliques at separate tables: PSYCHO-STONERS, led by LLOYD FIGG, giving each other dead arms. Lloyd’s the school’s premier delinquent. BULLY-JOCKS, led by the Quarterback, flirting with the PR QUEEN WANNABES at the next table. BAND NERDS, led by Derf, who chortle over a Mad Magazine trade music cassettes. Jeff finds a seat at a table against the back wall. The t is empty, except for OLIVER ZLATKA, 16, a sophomore and t school’s effeminate weakling. Jeff sits at the far end to lessen their association.
Hey. Jeff nods, keeping to himself. He shyly eats. OLIVER (CONT’D) I’m going away this summer to a wilderness camp. But in exchange my dad said I can get tickets to see Neil Sedaka in concert.
My favorite.
I know. Wanna go?
Um, sure. Prom Queen Wannabe WENDY WATKINS butts in--
(nudges Jeff) Hey, kid, you’re in my spot. Move.  12. Jeff slides closer to Oliver. Wendy stands on an empty ch and gets the crowd’s attention-- WENDY (CONT’D) Over here. Everyone!
Quiet.

Quiet. Thanks. I’m only talking to the seniors, so the rest of you just keep your traps shut. As you know, I’m on the Prom Planning Committee and I've - we've put our hearts into the event which is right around the corner. It’s going to be the best prom ever and just a reminder that voting for prom King and Queen ends this Friday. And, and it just came to my-- Figg knocks over Oliver's food tray.
Hey, Faggot. She’s talking. Laughter erupts.
Stop that--
You’re a little fruit.

Freakin’ juniors, stop that. Figg starts to give Oliver a wedgie in the aisle. Bully-J cheer him on. More widespread laughter and applause, even from Derf and his band-nerd cohorts. LUNCHROOM MONITORS swarm in and pull Figg away. In the confusion, Jeff slips out, undetected. He’s relieved he wasn’t the target.

At his work table, Jeff pulls a lumpy mass - wrapped in a undershirt - from his backpack. He unveils the fetal pig, stolen from Biology class. Jeff holds it preciously in hi palms and thumbs its belly.  13.
Jeff stares blankly at The Mary Tyler Moore Show as he finishes a bowl of cereal, blocking out his parents’ argu in the living room nearby--
I can’t believe you did that without discussing it first.
Why? You always say no to everything.
Joyce, I’m not paying for a crony drape hanger.
Interior decorator. There’s a difference. Dave sidles down the hall to get a look.
You're not capable of this kind of project. It needs attention, dedication. Next week you’re going to want to do pottery.
That’s hardly - I’m ready to go back to work.
What - how?
(gesturing to her son) David will be eleven. Lionel shoos David away.

He’s old enough to let himself in. Lynn Watkins up the street went back to work. Cynthia Bakula is selling real estate now, she’s not even around on the weekends. Even Jane Kyriazis is doing bookkeeping.
May I remind you, you’ve been back from the mental hospital for less than a year. Besides.  14. A strained pause. LIONEL (CONT’D) (walks away) Forget it.
Forget what?
... Just a month ago you saw a UFO fly past the house, and you chased it down the street in your bathrobe.
Jerk. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE’S BEDROOM - LATER Jeff and Dave lie in twin beds, forced to listen to their parents’ continued argument on the other side of the wall
GODDAMMIT, JOYCE, I’M NOT GOING TO have this argument again! It’s not even about that guy. Dave sniffles. Jeff wipes a tearful eye.
You're a fascist, you know that.
We're talking about nothing. We have nothing left to say to each other--
I have plenty, don’t get me started.
Shut the hell up.
I’ve had it with-- SLAM! A door shuts in a face. Absolute silence, except fo Dave's sniffling. Jeff slides over to his brother’s bed t comfort him.
Are they going to hit each other?
No, they just yell.  15.
MR. HICKS, the heavy-set armpit-stained band leader, cond a rehearsal. Jeff plays trumpet. In the back row, Derf pl tuba beside Kent on percussion. Mr. Hicks wraps up the so
That sounds excellent. The trumpet and clarinets were pitch perfect. A momentary proud smile crosses Jeff's face.
Groovy. You play like that at our year end recital and we’re gonna blow scalps off the audience... Band members sort of understand his latest idiom. MR. HICKS (CONT’D) «+. Once again, from the top.
Oliver lurks among the parked cars, hiding. Two BULLY-JOC find him and approach. Oliver backs up, timid.
Hey, faggot. There you are.
You've been avoiding us all day. Jeff appears - his backpack and trumpet case slung over h shoulder - not expecting to find anyone other than Oliver
Hey, Jeff.
Coming to save the day, Dahmer?
No, no--
Are you going to defend this homo with your trumpet case?
I got a trumpet you can blow.
I was just gonna tell him somethin’.  16.
Go ahead, I’d like to see this.
Forget it.
(blurts out) Jeff, I got the Neil Sedaka tickets for this Saturday. Jeff acts surprised, like he doesn’t know Oliver’s refere The bullies encroach on Oliver.
You guys going together? Cute.
I’m not going to any concert - it’s not my thing, you know.
But my dad said he’1l pick you up this Saturday around five... The Bully-Jocks beat up on Oliver - it’s routine. Jeff sl away, abandoning the scene for his own safety.
Lionel pulls into the driveway in his gray 1974 AMC Pacer grabs his leather briefcase and heads inside.
Lionel looks for Jeff around the house. He finds Dave in den watching Family Feud on TV.
Hi, Dave. So where’s your brother?
I think he’s in his lab. Been there for hours.
And your mother? Dave shrugs.  17.
LIONEL SWINGS OPEN THE DOOR AND BARGES IN. Jeff is busy examining rodent bones. The fetal pig is in a jar labeled Baby Pig.
Dad, you’re never home this early. Realizing the breadth of the dead animal collection, Lion SNATCHES several jars for a closer look.
Dad!?!
That’s enough, Jeff. Lionel leaves with the jars. Jeff's confused, but his attention quickly returns to the bone fragments. Suddenly, Lionel impetuously PULLS THE DOOR OFF THE HINGE
Dad! ?!
You're spending too much time in here. With a burst of adrenaline, Lionel stiff-arms Jeff to kee away and starts pulling more jars from the hut.

Don’t, don’t... A moment later; Lionel dumps the jars in the trash can. Jeff impotently circles the hut as Lionel continues to em it of its jars, acid, and other contents. Jeff moves to s some and prevent his father--

(assertive) I let you have a pet cemetery when you were a kid, but then this... Dave has wandered over and watches from a distance. LIONEL (CONT’D) You need, Jeff, to come out, to come out of your shell, something more normal.  18.
I’m in the band. I’m--

You're not hearing me. Lionel drags out the work table. LIONEL (CONT’D) I don’t understand what happened... He pushes and sways the hut, loosening its construction. tears it apart until it COLLAPSES, revealing Jeff shudder with fear. Jeff's most contained obsession is now history Lionel catches his breath. Jeff and Dave stand around and look at the flattened hut as Lionel drags the trashcan aw
Jeff hides the contents of one jar (which he clearly swip behind a tree. He covers the bones with leaves.
Lionel, Jeff, and Dave pick at leftovers for dinner. Dave hums as he eats, while Jeff pouts. Joyce is absent.
You always liked performing as a kid. Jeff, maybe... how about doing theater? Or something else? Any of it could... At least help your acceptance to college. Silence.
Jeff keeps to himself, head lowered, in the back of class
Jeff eats by himself. SCHOOL SPIRIT approaches, gregariou

Wanna sign up for Key Club? (no response) We're looking for new recruits who can be active over the summer. Just because school’s out, it doesn’t mean we stop helping people in our community. Would you like to help others in your community?  19.
No.
Derf, Kent, and Mike are joined by buddy NEIL, also a jokester but the most empathetic of the bunch. They take turns tossing a broken bike pedal into a garbage pail, li game of horse, wasting time...
We're still trapped in this wasteland for another year. Jeff creeps past.
I know - it might drive me crazy. Senior year’s going to suck, I’m ready to get out. Jeff starts to approach, hoping to join in their game. A tense TEACHER pops out of the side door--
Hey, are you in an after-school program?
Not right now--
Tennis season is over.
Marching band is only in the fall--

Well then, get off school grounds. The day’s over. You can’t be hanging around with nothing to do. Go, get... Derf, Kent, Mike and Neil withdraw, tittering. None of th notice Jeff nearby. He cuts the other way. Figg body checks Jeff.
Wanna catch a buzz? Cupped in Figg’s hand is a joint.  20.

Straight off the boat. Seven bucks. (no response) Yesterday, I freakin toked-up and hit a thousand in mailbox baseball. Hesitantly considering it, Jeff checks his pockets. They’ empty except for a PLASTIC BAG.
Why the bag, dude?
I pick up roadkill, but I’m trying to quit.
I’1l get you roadkill. Stick with me. Figg drifts by, already onto his next potential customer.

Jeff sits beside the flattened hut. He FONDLES the small, recovered collection of rodent-size bones. Then, the Neighborhood Jogger runs up the street, approaching. Jeff checks his watch as he edges closer to street. He lurks in the bushes, waiting. The Neighborhood Jogger trots past Jeff's house. Jeff's breathing quickens, excited. Trailing the jogger, Jeff weaves through the bushes.

Jeff JUMPS OUT onto the shoulder of the road. He scurries hesitantly, up the incline CHASING AFTER THE JOGGER. Further up the slope, the jogger passes Wendy Watkins (th prom queen wannabe). She’s retrieving mail. Her IRISH SET yaps at the jogger’s heels. She pulls at the leash.

I’m so sorry, so sorry. Jeff slows, keeping a distance. He watches the jogger run away. Checks his watch once again.  21. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE'’S BEDROOM - EVENIN Jeff stares out the window, eyes locked on a squirrel sta right back at him, frozen on a branch. Lionel drops by.
What are you doing?
Stu-studying for finals.

Can I have a minute? Look, I went through it too. It’s completely normal. Puberty is this period when your sex glands become functional and your hypothalamus signals hormonal changes that stimulate the pituitary. Then, the gonads and testis... anyway, it’s an awkward time. You mustn’t forget all boys go through it too, not just you, so there’s no reason to be shy.
That’s not it, Dad.
Try me. I spoke to someone at work about - I’m ready to listen.
Most everyone's known me since elementary school, they’re not going to change their minds now. It’1l be easier after I graduate.

But you can’t - look... okay... the hut... You have to understand, Jeff, I just get mad at you sometimes because I see in you things I don’t like about myself. I spend too much time in the chemistry lab, I know. I just want you to be more active than I was, have friends in a way I never really... so... I have something. Lionel steps away. He returns and presents TWO DUMBBELLS. LIONEL (CONT’D) I picked these up at The Summit Mall. It'll help, I think. (MORE )

You'll be more impressive, you might find it rewarding. And maybe some girl might notice you. Right? Okay? Jeff stares back, blankly. Lionel sets the dumbbells down withdraws. Jeff pushes them away with his heel. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE’S BEDROOM - THAT NI Jeff hears his parents bickering again.
You have to start somewhere--
It makes no sense. It’s ugly. How much?
Just a hundred and twenty-five dollars.
For a pink fucking foot stool? That’s ludicrous, Joyce! DESPERATE KNOCKS at the door. Jeff has placed the dumbbel as doorstops. He moves them away and lets in Dave. Jeff p out:
I think we should divorce.
Divorce!?! Over this foot stool?
YOU DON’T BELIEVE ME? Jeff barges out.
Jeff SNAPS, vehemently knocking over a lamp.
Will you stop! Stop it.
Jeff.
Stop. Fighting. Seriously.  23.
Dammit. This doesn’t concern you.

Go to your room, Jeff. Jeff stews, staring at them. Odd panting. The room is tig with tension. Then, Jeff obediently retreats. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE'’S BEDROOM - CONTIN Jeff locks the door. Eyes well up with tears. A jumble of emotions. He returns one dumbbell to the door and takes t other one to his bed. Dave watches as Jeff starts doing b curls, furiously.
BATH, OHIO during a carefree July day. TEENAGERS roam on bicycles. CHILDREN play in a park. KIDS jump into the town pool.
Jeff rallies with Neil. Jeff hits a winning forehand.
Wow, nice slice. Why didn’t you hit like that last season? Jeff shrugs, not comfortable with compliments, as he fetc balls. Neil fetches his water.
I’m heading over to the pool to cool off. Wanna come? Jeff considers it, then shakes his head no.
Ah, C’mon.
Jeff treads water in the deep end. Fixated on a group of young boys frolicking nearby. He goggles at their lean, weightless bodies glistening in the water.  24.
Jeff, Jeff, move over. I’m gonna dive right on you. Jeff swims away. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE'’S BEDROOM - DAY Jeff sits at the edge of his bed doing more bicep curls.
Jeff sets a small, makeshift trap. He eyes a squirrel nea
Several seniors paint “Class of ‘78 Rules” on the school rock. In the b.g., Jeff walks through the front entrance.

Jeff trudges down the hall. He’s taller and more muscular after a growth spurt and summer spent lifting weights. He fits into his father’s hand-me-down dress shirt and slack and carries his old, leather briefcase. In contrast to th colorful 70s fashion in full bloom, this, ironically, cas studious appearance to teachers scanning the halls.
MR. FEDELE, a jovial scatterbrain, struggles to get comma of his classroom.

Everyone, quiet down. I know it’s exciting to catch up after summer break. Jeff is detached in the back row. MR. FEDELE (CONT’D) I have rules, I must go over, I have rules. Your attention, students. But no one in class really cares. Fedele’s weak reputatio precedes him. Students pass notes and gossip. Derf doodle cartoon of Fedele for an audience of onlookers. MR. FEDELE (CONT’D) That’s enough. Quiet. Alright, good. Thank you. Mr. Fedele starts passing out textbooks from the stack.  25. MR. FEDELE (CONT’D) Your senior year American History Honors class will focus on Federal Government and our Presidents. Why is history important? Mr. Fedele notices Jeff hunkered down in the back. MR. FEDELE (CONT’D) You. Why is history important? Jeff mumbles. MR. FEDELE (CONT’D) What?
(mumbling) Uh, it’s important... dunno.
You all must speak clearly.
(mumbling, like a moan) I dunno. Chortles from students. Derf turns. Jeff mumbles again - time intentionally for attention. Laughter escalates. The reaction surprises Jeff. He smirks, then:
BRRRRRAAAA dunno. Laughter ERUPTS.
Quiet! Let me answer. We can only really know about ourselves if we come to better understand our past. Turn to page ten in your new text books.
RIIING. The period bell halts Fedele’s lecture. Kids head the door.

Wait, before you forget, take a permission slip and packets home for our spring trip to DC. Everyone must get a parent to sign it.  26. A fellow student approvingly pats Jeff on the shoulder as they head out. Jeff grins.
A DRAMA GEEK finishes her audition song:
If happy little bluebirds fly beyond the rainbow, Why, oh why can’t I?

Thank you, very nice, Melody, beautiful as always. (scanning the audition sign- up sheet) Next up, Oliver Zlatka. Oliver scampers onto the stage. Jeff is in the audience, slouched in a seat against the w
Hi, Oliver. Apologies. Unfortunately, I was instructed by the PTA to do a musical this year, to be more inclusive.
(sings off key) Somewhere over the rainbow, way up high, There’s a land that I’ve heard of, once in a lullaby. Jeff wipes nervous beads of sweat from his forehead.
Somewhere over the rainbow, skies are blue, And the dreams... Oliver stops himself, knowing his audition is awful. An awkward silence. Oliver exits the auditorium, head down.
Next up. Jeff Dahmer. Musical Director waits. No one comes on stage.

Jeff Dahmer? Those scattered around the seats look around. Jeff covers face. A look of self-doubt comes over him. He slips out.  27. MUSICAL DIRECTOR (CONT’D) Okay, lost your chance. Next up is Alan Tomczak.

Jeff sits at a reading table scanning the quiet scene. He studies a pack of STUDENTS doing homework at another tabl light bulb goes off... Jeff GROWLS. LOUDER AND LOUDER, evolving into a widesprea moan. Shoulders jerk up.
... Baaaaaaa! Arrrr! Baaaaa! Totally unexpected, the other students laugh. MRS. WOODARD, the irascible librarian, STORMS IN from a b aisle. Finds everyone reading, swallowing their amusement

Who did that!? She beelines it over to the table of snickering students. MRS. WOODARD (CONT’D) Was it you? Behave yourself or get out of my library. They remain tight-lipped. Mrs. Woodard looks around, then returns to her chores filing away books. Again, it goes quiet... then:
(moaning) Brrra! Thmaaa! More snickers. Mrs. Woodard bursts in, again. She’s FUMIN Still no clue--
Who keeps making that noise? Jeff lowers his head. A smirk creeps across his face. Fee a connection to the other kids.
Jeff passes Neil and his friends, including Derf, and hin
Hey man, watch this.  28. Jeff steps into the middle of the main hallway and throws sudden, sprawling

His arms FLAIL. His tongue wags out of his mouth. It’s hilarious and bizarre. A crowd gathers. Laughter and cheers. Derf, Neil, Mike, and Kent rush over for a front row view Widespread laughter from the swelling crowd. Though, a fe straight-laced kids flee in confusion. Jeff continues spazzing, center stage. He gets in a batter’s stance demonstrate when, out of the corner of his eye, he spots Neighborhood Jogger trotting up the hill. Sparks arousal. Jeff creeps closer to the road, clenches the bat. HUFF! H The jogger approaches. Thigh muscles flex. Chest pounds. Soiled in sweat.  58. Jeff glares at the passing jogger. He unconsciously holds bat upright & erect.
Jeff, what about me? Breaking Jeff's spell. He drops the bat and heads inside.
Joyce interrupts Dave doing homework. She gives him kisse a chipper, manipulative manner.

David, honey, have you thought about what’s wrong with your father? (Dave shakes his head) Well, let me tell you... He’s selfish, he’s unreasonable, he’s-- Compelled to interject, Jeff approaches. Joyce glares at
Why are you being so hard on Dad?
Get away. Has nothing to do with you. Becomes a mother-son stand off. Jeff retreats to his bedr
Dave, how would you like to live near Grandma and Grandpa?
A local greasy spoon/truck stop. Lionel and his two sons dinner in a booth. Lionel looks stressed. Jeff plays with food, garnering confidence to ask:
Dad? Is Mom going back... to the hospital?
Why do you ask?
She's acting a lot like she did before she went the last time.
How so?  59.
She never talks to me. Or asks how I’m doing? Am I in her way?
Don’t be silly. So, are there any girls in school that you like?
Mom said she’s moving to Wisconsin to live with Grandma.
She did. When?
She told me, I dunno. Yesterday.
Your mother is doing better. I wouldn’t take what she says at face value, but she’s doing much better than before.
(interrupting) Jeff. Derf with his parents - CAROL & RICHARD BACKDERF - and younger brother pass by, headed to the register.
Hey.
Mom, Dad, this is my friend Dahmer. Jeff Dahmer. Lionel perks up. Parents shake hands, exchanging names.
Where’s Mrs. Dahmer?
She’s home, a bit under the weather.
Dad, Jeff's dad is also a chemist.
I’m at The Firestone. After ten years at The Goodyear.  60.
Really. I’m at the Goodrich Research Center. No longer working on SBRs though.
New monomers in the mix.
Just spent a year on macrogalleria.
Really.
Well, it’s nice meeting you.
Yes.
Have a good holiday.
Jeff, did you hear? Oliver Zlatka committed suicide two days ago.
No.
Yes, tragic.
His photo’s in the County Weekly. Richard flashes the front page with OLIVER ZLATKA'’S PHOT
A real shame.
I hear... well, it’s hard for some. He was teased, I hear.
I like Oliver. He’s nice.
They live near us. Horrible.
Yes. Well, anyway, nice to meet you.  61.
When’s the funeral?
The paper said the day after Thanksgiving. Regret and sorrow cross Jeff's face.
Jeff attends the funeral. Graveside as the coffin arrives Jeff finds himself SUDDENLY AROUSED. He covers his erecti in his slacks. He slinks away before the coffin is lowere
Jeff and Dave decorate their scrawny Christmas tree. Thei parents fight in the next room--
You should move out in the new year.
I’M ALREADY SLEEPING ON THE SOFA.

head_text.subj: I WILL TAKE DAVE TO MY MOTHER'S.

text: Jeff swells with sadness and leaves the house, unnoticed.
Jeff gets on his bike and rides out.
Jeff peddles the moonlit road. Tears run down his face. A buzzes past, blaring its horn.
Jeff trolls another back road. He rides up to a FROZEN OPOSSUM just lying there. He relishes in the discovery an eagerly pulls a plastic bag from his pocket.  62.
Jeff carries his stuffed plastic bag down a narrow trail, leading him deeper into the woods. Jeff arrives at a

Hidden among thick brush and tall trees. Jeff lays the de opossum on a rock. He takes out his (stolen) knife and meticulously dissects the road kill, first stripping away flesh, then fondling the entrails in his hands.

CU: JEFF'S FINGERNAILS. Remnants of dried blood underneat his thumbnail. He inconspicuously scrapes it out. It’s the start of the Senior Trip to Washington DC. Jeff laughs, with his Dahmer Fan Club buddies. A more relaxed, relieved glow on his face - a break from home does him go
And the Dahmer Fan Club has to leave our mark on DC. Something grand.
Boo-yah, something classic. Like what?
A spazz on the White House lawn?
You can’t get on the White House lawn. Derf looks around. He lands on CHARLIE SMITH, the one bla student, a burly guy.
Well for one... Charlie, as the token black in our class, let’s get some Super 8 of you on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial giving Martin Luther King’s I Have A Dream speech.
Good one, loser.
The Dahmer Fan Club will stand behind you like--
I play football, Backderf, not charades.  63.
Cut!
Fine, good one. We'll think of something. Jeff notes the brainstorm. He gazes out the window. A hig sign reads: I-70E WASHINGTON and I-76 HARRISBURG.
Teachers call out pairs of names and hand out room keys.
Jeffrey Dahmer and Charlie Smith, you have Room 327.
Charlie takes the bed by the window. Jeff hesitantly wait the door for Charlie to settle in. From the hallway--
Dahmer, we're right here. (whispers) If he rapes you in the middle of the night, just knock.
Very funny. Jeff drops his bag on his bed.
So, we’re roommates, huh...
Yep. Charlie turns on the TV, switches it to Three’s Company. the clip: Janet sustains Mr. Roper’s belief that Jack is CHARLIE SMITH (CONT’D) So obvious.
Huh?

Mr. Roper’s an idiot. Taxi’s on ina few.  64. Charlie crosses to the bathroom with his toothbrush. Jeff eyes follow. He pulls off his shirt and watches TV, shirtless. The credits roll. Jeff waits. Charlie returns, though still disinterested in chatting.
I’m curious... is it hard being the only black kid in our class?
Ehh.

Your palms are less black. You think your insides are the same color as mine? Is my stomach and your stomach the same color? Charlie gives Jeff an intimidating stare, silencing the chitchat. Charlie lays supine on his bed as Taxi starts. sneaks a couple glances at his built body.

MONTAGE as Jeff AND HIS SENIOR CLASS approach the WASHING MONUMENT. Neil photographs Derf on his back - the landmar his erection. They scale THE CAPITOL BUILDING steps where Jeff throws a quick spazz. They line THE WHITE HOUSE fence, like jailbirds.
Kids, since World War Two, public access to The White House grounds has been increasingly restricted. But maybe you can see President Carter through a window.
Let us in! Let me in! Nearby, a cluster of protestors hold up signs: No Nukes, Needs Oil? I Ride The Bus, Don’t Trust The Shah.
Jeff and his pals play poker, and chow on soda and snacks Jeff wins the hand.
Damn, Dahmer. Thought you had nothin’.  65.
He’s got a poker face.
Beginner's luck, I guess. Neil deals another hand.
Dahmer, Man of Mystery. Totally my next cartoon. Jeff smiles, enjoying the camaraderie. It’s good to be aw
Jeff, Derf, Penny, and Neil stroll along Constitutional A
Totally bogus we didn’t meet the President. Could’ve met our State Senators back in Ohio, you know?
Let's call Carter, see if he’s free.
That’s ridiculous.
That's impossible.
How about Vice President Mondale? Jeff heads to the nearest pay phone stall. He steps insid Derf follows, amused.
(into pay phone) Hi. Yes, I’d like the number for the Vice President of The United States. His office number, please. Derf chuckles. Neil and Penny idle by, skeptical.
This is pointless. It’s our last day here, we should get lunch... Jeff talks on the phone. Derf gestures to Penny & Neil.
It’s ringing.  66. Jeff starts talking--
He’s talking to an Aide. Derf leans in to listen--

(into phone) ... And we’re from Revere High in Ohio, just in the middle of nowhere, and my friends and I are honor students and on the school newspaper, and we're all very interested in politics, and I was wondering if we could interview you on what it’s like to work as an aide to the Vice President of The United States. (listens) Uh, huh. Sure. We’re on Constitutional Avenue. Uh, huh. Great. Jeff hangs up.
We're in.
What? C’mon.
Dahmer’s got balls, man. He’s slick.
We have an appointment in an hour.
The AIDE gives Jeff, Derf, Neil, and Penny a tour.
And you get to sit in meetings with the Vice President?
Sometimes.
Really? Where’s his office.

Down that hall. Let’s see if he’s in.  67. INT. VICE PRESIDENT WALTER MONDALE’S OFFICE - DAY VICE PRESIDENT WALTER MONDALE reviews documents with a Cabinet Member. The teens wait in a line near the door, nervous. The Vice President approaches.

Kids, thanks for dropping by. I have a moment before a call with Indira Gandhi, who just resigned as Prime Minister of India. Where are you from? Jeff's heart pounds, in awe. VP WALTER MONDALE (CONT’D) Ohio’s a great state. So, what do each of you want to be when you grow up? The Vice President looks to Derf.
I, like, want to draw cartoons, not for TV. I want to draw comics, yeah.
Well, that’s great, as long as you don’t draw any political ones making fun of me.
Of course not. Jeff stiffens. The Vice President finally reaches him--
And so, what interests you? All heads turn. His friends are curious, as well.
Biology.
Great. You should pursue that. The Vice President shakes Jeff's clean hand.
They race away from the building, soaring and giddy. They gratefully pat Jeff on the back.  68.
That was the coolest thing I’ve ever done in my life. I can die now. Dahmer, I can die now, thank you. Jeff basks in their congratulations.

The bus rumbles into the Revere High parking lot as the t reaches it’s definitive end. Out the window, parents eage await the return of their kids. Despondent over the retur grave curtain of darkness returns to Jeff's face.
Jeff sulks back to his father’s car.
You have a good time? Y’alright?
Uh-huh. It was great.
You don’t look well. You have a fever?
I don’t think so.
A converted living room lined with chairs. Two children babble and play, just beyond arm’s length of their mother The kids suck on new lollipops.
Careful. The mother makes departing small talk and leaves with her kids. A NURSE appears with a clipboard.
Mr. Jeffrey Dahmer. ANGLE ON Jeff Dahmer seated against the far wall.
Yes, that’s me. The nurse shuffles down a hallway. He follows.  69.

Jeff waits, seated on the examination table in his underw He looks around at the cabinets, jars of cotton balls and gauze, the weight scale, the eye chart. Dr. York enters, sucking on a lollipop - it’s the Neighborhood Jogger at work. He glances at the clipboard.
Are you running a cold?
(represses his excitement) I think so. I’ve been getting chills.
Always nice to see new patients.
A physical, maybe? Jeff stiffens as Dr. York moves in, on his swivel chair.
Stick out your tongue. Say Ahhh.
Abhhh.
Tonsils look good. Turn. Let me see your ears...
Do you do surgery?
No.
Why not?
I like caring for patients but I’m not the type to wanna cut someone open. So this, but almost became a podiatrist.
Less blood.
Exactly.  70.
What about what’s on a patient’s mind?
You mean, a psychiatrist?
My mom had one. Dr. York puts his stethoscope against Jeff's chest and ba Jeff fights his quick breathing.
So far, you look healthy. Okay, before I weigh you. Do you hurt when you pee?
Huh? No.
Are you sexually active?
What kind, sort of...
You’re at the age. No growths, okay. Pull down your underwear. Jeff pulls down his underwear.
Cough. Cough again. Cough again. Suddenly, a stalled silence. He returns to his clipboard. awkward tension between them, implies Jeff became erect.
Pull up your pants, I’m finished. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE'’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Standing in the same position, Jeff finishes jerking off. KNOCK. Another KNOCK.
Just a minute, go away, just a minute. He sharpens up and pulls up his pants.
The Dahmer Family rush out of the house. Lionel and the b are in suits, Joyce in a dress. They scramble into a car.  71.
Remember, please, behave yourself. It’s my boss and work associates--
Boys, he doesn’t even know the groom.
It’s my boss’s son, which is all the same. Kids, there’1l be some other kids there your age.
It’s cocktail hour. Jeff approaches the bar.
My Dad wants a Jack and coke.
(distrustful) Where is he?
Over there.
Which one?
On the other side... I swear... He spots Joyce slipping out with a sleazy PERENNIAL BACHE
Sorry, kid, he’ll have to come get it himself. Jeff leaves the bar, then swipes an almost empty cocktail glass from a busboy’s tray.
Jeff sits, sober, with his father and brother.
Lionel, and where’s your wife?
She's, uh, not feeling well. Headache. Went to rest in the car.  72.
Lionel finds Joyce fixing her makeup in a hallway mirror. Perennial Bachelor idles feet away.
Where have you been? Dinner was served a half hour ago.
I was fucking that guy over there. The Perennial Bachelor slips back into the party, avoidin
He’s your boss’s cousin, staying here at the hotel. I might just stay the night. If you won’t divorce me, then deal with it. Lionel swallows his pride and anger.
But, at home, he furiously packs two suitcases.
I’ve had enough. You’re a mess and impossible... I’m done with you.
Good. Lionel storms out. Jeff follows, helpless.
Lionel reverses out of the driveway.
Don’t, dad, don’t...
Finally. Jeff runs off.
Jeff stumbles through the woods, unraveling, agonizing. H WHACKS a fallen branch against a tree repeatedly... drain himself. The sound travels... A KITCHEN LIGHT turns on.  73.
Jeff WHACKS tennis balls in every direction, spazzing out his teammates. Neil stops rallying to watch.
Jeff Dahmer, if you don’t clean up your act, you’re off the team. Jeff stops. He drops his racquet and WALKS OFF.
Jeff pounds a fifth of gin in no time. Slurps the last dr
The Dahmer Fan Club hangs around Derf’s Chevy Vegas, listening to Buzzard Radio 101 WMMS. Jeff shuffles by.
Dahmer. Dahmier, boy. Wanna hang?
How about later? Whitey’s for burgers and arcade - they just got Death Race.
Nah. Jeff veers away, disengaging...
Balderelli polices the main thoroughfare. With cunning, J avoids and staggers by, gripping his leather briefcase, t BUMPS into two students. They smell the alcohol.
Dang.
In a dark room, a corny 1960s 16mm anti-drug educational unspools for students. MR. LAPOLLA monitors the projector
I’m glad I didn’t jump off that bridge. It’s much higher than it looked.
I really think you should talk to someone. LSD is dangerous.  74.
Most young people think they’re stronger and have more willpower than they actually do. Jeff opens the door, tries to slip in undetected--
You're late, Mr. Dahmer. Again.
And one of the potentials for drug traffic is the school. Jeff trips over a student in the front row.
Watch it, Jerk! (smells Jeff's boozy breath) Yuck, arrr, Damn.
S-S-Sorry. Disoriented, Jeff BLOCKS THE LIGHT from the projector. Blinded, he struggles to find a path to an empty chair.
Here the connection can be found with these peddlers of misery who prey on the unwary, the uninformed, the curious, the thrill-seekers...
Move it, Dahmer, get a seat!

++. Most young people will continue through life as normal, responsible citizens. Others, the shunted and unloved, are the candidates for the slave world of lifelong drug addiction. Jeff drops into a chair, and lowers his sad, lonely face. NARRATOR FOR FILM (CONT’D) But no-one is immune. How does it happen? Where does it start? What are the signs?  75.
A huddled cluster of upperclassmen get high and drink, al with one youthful teacher, MR. PITT. Passing around a joi
You blow up some gooks?
If I told you, I’d have to kill you too.
Awesome. C’mon. Nearby, Jeff drinks by his lonesome. His stash and finish bottles are tucked under a log.
Shit, dude, look, Balderelli. Heads turn. In the distance, Vice Principal Balderelli crosses the practice field, approaching.

Run. The stoners and Mr. Pitt scatter. Jeff doesn’t freak out just lies down behind the log, playing dead. Balderelli steps into the woods and looks around. Smells pot and goes further in... ducking under branches. He pas right by Jeff, but doesn’t see him. Then, spots a couple stoners making a run for it across the practice field.
Hey, I SEE YOU. STOP RIGHT THERE. Balderelli storms out of the woods and chases them down. sits back up and continues drinking.
Drafts of the yearbook layout are pinned to a bulletin bo Derf, Neil, and Mike enthusiastically rush in.
It’s here!

Dahmer’s got to see this. We should get him. Neil, see if he’s around.  76. Yet, they cannot contain themselves and rip open the pack They spread out the developed club photos. Laughter swell over sight of Jeff's face in many.
.-. And here he is again!
So bad, it’s so bad! Their YEARBOOK ADVISOR enters. She’s a snippy woman.
Good, they came in. Let’s see. She scans the photos, realizing the prank. YEARBOOK ADVISOR (CONT’D) What is Jeff Dahmer - he’s not in any of these clubs. Who did this?
He’s not?

He doesn’t belong in Debate or here or this one. She grabs a wide black marker and BLOTCHES OUT JEFF’S FAC all the club photos, a fitting symbol. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE'’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Jeff stares at the wall, mouthing the lyrics to Black Sabbath’s “Iron Man” playing on his cassette player.
Is he alive or dead? Has he thoughts within his head? We'll just pass him there, Why should we even care?
Joyce is deeply absorbed on the phone. Jeff approaches.
(into phone) Is he out of his mind? I can’t believe that’s his position. He’s being completely irrational.
Mom.  77.
(into phone) There’s no way I'd give custody of Dave over. Never in a million years.
Mom.

(to Jeff) Shhh. (back to phone) He’s g-g-getting everything. I’M NOT BEING IRRATIONAL. YOU HEAR ME? YOU’RE MY LAWYER, NOT HIS. DAYS? I WON’T DISCUSS HIS CUSTODY. Jeff swipes hot dogs from the fridge and slinks out.
Lurking in the bushes, Jeff lures Wendy Watkins’ Irish Se over to him with his raw hot dogs.
Good dog. Jeff unlatches the dog from its run line.

Jeff leads the dog to the same spot where he once tore ap the frozen opossum. Jeff takes out his knife. His teeth chatter, readying for the kill. The dog sits, panting, wagging its tail. Jeff approaches, knife in hand. He pulls the dog to his SLAUGHTER ROCK, where remnants of rodent skulls are scatt around. The dog yaps. Its tail continues to wag. But, at the last moment... Jeff cannot do it. He TOSSES the knife aside.
Go on! Go! Go home. Get! The dog runs off. Jeff drops to his knees.
Mr. Fedele takes attendance. He notes Jeff’s absence.  78.
Mr. Jeff Dahmer, absent again. That’s five times in the last two weeks.
(whispers) We need our mascot back... Life’s not as much fun around here.
I know.
Maybe we should just let him be, you know? He’s not--
C'mon, Neil. It’s all - he likes the attention.
Maybe so. But... Neil keeps his thoughts to himself.
Jeff finishes the last drop from a fifth of vodka.
Parents hurriedly pick up their kids from after-school practices & rehearsals. They pass Jeff slouched on the fr steps, sobering up.
Mr. Dahmer, another long day hitting the books?
Yep. He turns away to conceal his sozzled self.
In her Oldsmobile Omega, Joyce pulls into a parking spot. Dave sits in the passenger seat. Jeff sits in the back. Lionel’s already there, waiting by his car.  79.

Just a minute, before you spend the day with your father, I need to talk to him. Stay in the car. Joyce takes a set of legal documents and gets out. Jeff quickly steals some loose cash from her purse. Both sons hear something, and look out the rear window. T watch in stunned paralysis as: Joyce and Lionel get in each other’s faces, talking forcefully. Joyce waves the legal papers in the air. Suddenly, Joyce blows her lid. She shoves Lionel. She sla at him, yelling. Retaliating, veins pop out of Lionel’s n He holds her arms down. She kicks him. He kicks her back. shoves her away. She runs right back at him, flailing her arms, losing papers to the ground. RANDOM ADULTS rush over to break it up. They separate Joy and Lionel. Joyce is crying, and threatening him. All wor are muffled inside the car as the kids watch, helpless. Joyce returns to the car, fuming. She rummages for her ke She pulls out in a rage.
I thought we were going to see Daddy. Jeff glares at his mom.
Jeff buys more alcohol from a HIGH SCHOOL DROPOUT.
You’re my best customer. Jeff takes the large bottle of vodka and drops it into hi leather briefcase, revealing how he transports it undetec
Rows of parked cars. It’s quiet with class in session. Co Natale wanders through on a cigarette break and discovers Jeff behind a car drinking.
Hey! What’s this? On school grounds. What’s your name?  80.
J-Jeff.
What do you have to say for yourself?
(puts on an act) It’s just... My parents are splitting up and I’m pretty depressed about it and I thought drinking might help--
I’m sorry about your folks-- INT. VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER
But that’s no excuse. It’s not as bad as it seems.
Little late for that.
It’s no excuse, period. Here’s the deal. You have a choice. I can either phone your parents and tell them what you did or you can take ten licks and not drink again. Your call.
Don’t call my parents.
Your choice... ooookay. Balderelli pulls a paddle from his desk drawer.
Really?

Bend over and grab the wall. Jeff's stunned. He puts his hands on the wall. Balderelli winds up and WHACKS Jeff in the ass. Jeff drops to his kn VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI (CONT’D) Get up. He returns to his position and receives a paddling. Each strike is worse than the last.  81. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE’S BEDROOM - THAT NI Alone, Jeff paces. A sore limp from the paddling lingers. swirl of depraved thoughts, his dismantling family, his o inner-disgust brings him to tears. Haunted:

Okay... alright... okay... alright... Tears slide down his face. He drops onto his bed and curl beside the DEAD NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER, stiff and speechless Jeff finds comfort. Jeff holds the dead jogger tight.
(mutters) Don’t leave me, don’t leave me. CUT TO WIDE SHOT of Jeff in bed alone. The dead Neighborh Jogger is a fantasy.

Derf doodles a cartoon of Dahmer in his notebook. Class discussion of Faulkner's As I Lay Dying is background noi TAP TAP on the window gets his attention. Outside the win Jeff POPS his head up and GROWLS at him. Derf chuckles.
Mr. Backderf. Are you with us?
A field party. Bully-jocks, Psycho-Stoners, Band Nerds ar all there. Beer cans. Making out. The Dahmer Fan Club shotgun beers. Several Bully-Jocks impose:
Look, the Rah Rah band nerds drink.
Yeah, whatdya you think, we’d?--
Lightweights--
Be home playin’ snare drum.
Snap.  82.
More active than standing on the sidelines.
Dang.
Good one. Y’alright for a turd. Where’s your mascot, Dumb Dahmer?
He’s not here--
He gonna be your prom date, Backderf?
Your mother might, if she can fit ina dress.
Dahmer’s like your little court jester. ‘Cept he’s not hangin’ with you much anymore.
The fan club lives on.
Really? Looks like he ditched ya.
Just think he’s confused--
And looks like Neil’s a little protective.
And passing out cartoon flyers is getting kinda old, don’t ya think?
He’s still into it.
I dunno. Seems like you’re closing out your high school career shucked by the fool.
Makes you the fools that you are.
We'll get him to show up.
For what?
Uh. A rockin’ command performance. He’1ll ante up. For sure.
Doubt it.
(aside, to Kent & Mike) Let’s just do it. Let’s get him to take his spazz to the max--
Derf, he’s hasn't spazzed in weeks.
He’s not really interested in a whole lot anymore. Better not--
Yeah but, what if we pay him? I’11l put in five bucks. (drops cash in his cap) Gets ‘em out on a Saturday.
I’m in. It‘’1l be killer.
He’1l surely blow it on booze.
(to Neil) C’mon, man, put in some. I’m taking a pot.
Yeah, for his booze fund. Neil shakes his head, disapproving.
Nuh-uh.
Chill, Neil. Bully-Jock Jerkoff pays in. 83.  84.
I'll believe it when I see it. Derf and Mike start to circulate, selling more tickets.
Derf stops Jeff in his stuporous path. Jeff bleeps, BRAAA
Hey, Jeff. So, look, we got an idea for the Fan Club... Onlooking, Neil steps away, remarks--
(to Kent) We should just leave him alone. He’s not a side show attraction. BACK TO Derf, wrapping up his plan with Jeff--
Great. Here’s thirty-two bucks. It’1l be your Command Performance. We might have more by Saturday. Jeff nods, half-coherent.
Derf and Kent arrive in the Chevy Vegas. They head to the kitchen door and knock. Jeff opens the door.
Gweeetings.
Ready?
Just a sec. Jeff heads back to retrieve something. Derf and Kent deci to tiptoe into the house.
(chuckling) Where’s that pink foot stool? They head through the kitchen and discover depressive Joy Dahmer slouched over at the dining room table, quivering.  85.
Hiii boyzzzz. Derf and Kent stiffen up. The pink foot stool is tipped o on its side, abandoned in corner.
Ready? Jeff is in the kitchen, with a jacket draped over a paper grocery bag, under his arm. Derf and Kent follow him out.
It’s drizzling. The worn wipers stutter across the windshield. Derf drives with Kent in the passenger seat. sits in the back, straddling the center hump.
(glances in rearview mirror) You’re blocking my view. Sit on either side, Dahmer.

I’m good. Jeff pulls a six-pack of Busch beer from the paper bag. H pops open a can and flauntingly gulps it down like water. crushes the can and drops it on the floor, then repeats. uncomfortable to watch, so they chatter:
Is Cooper coming?
He said he was.
And what about Borowski and Guentlzer?
Guentlzer is but Borowski didn’t pay. We'll see who in ten minutes. Derf peeks in the rear view mirror. Jeff pounds another b then another. His “aura of doom” makes Derf twinge.
I never seen ya drink like that before, Dahmer.
Well, here I am.  86.
They pull into the Summit Mall Parking lot. Jeff burps in backseat, already finished with his beers.
In a daze, Jeff follows Derf and Kent to the main entranc
Where we meeting these idiots?
Right in front of the Orange Julius.
I’m psyched.
Derf and Kent, with Jeff trailing, spot the pack of paid SPECTATORS, numbering nearly a dozen upperclassmen.
‘Bout time! (hands Jeff cash) Another fifteen bucks. Not bad. Jeff stuffs the cash in his pocket.
Ok. Let’s do this. One teenager pulls out an 8mm camera. Others start commen and snickering with anticipation.
We present Jeff--
Jeffrey. For this I’m Jeffrey.
The Dahmer Fan Club presents Jeffrey Dahmer in his Command Performance. Derf pats Jeff on the back, gesturing forward...
(whispers in Jeff's ear) Welcome to the wild world of wasteful capitalism. Why don’t you show them what it’s all about?  87.

Glllaaaaaaadddd-11lleeee. Jeff walks down the main shopping hallway toward innocent shoppers. The teenage pack trail him at a distance. And like its origins in the high school hallway, Jeff thr an EPIC EPILEPTIC-LIKE SPAZZ, flailing his arms and legs.
Unsuspecting SHOPPERS turn heads, spooking many. Some scu away with children. The teenage-pack roars with laughter, snorting, falling over each other.

Oh, Man! That was awesome. Where is he? Boo-yah. Over there? Get closer. Jeff chases THREE MIDDLE-SCHOOL GIRLS, moaning and grunti in their wake. The girls dip into the bathroom for safety THE TEENAGE-PACK (CONT’D) Did you get that on camera? Jeff continues plodding through the mall, spooking more a more shoppers with flares of fits--
Uh! Uh! Uh! Uh! UUUUUUUUH! A mother grabs her child. An elderly couple scurry into a clothing store. Jeff approaches a FOOD CLERK passing out free samples. He takes two handfuls in his mouth.
